QuantumSure Documentation

Get started with our API, integration guides, and best practices for implementing quantum-resistant cryptography.

  • Usage Guide
  • Sharing Guide

  • QuantumSure Encryption at a Glance

Usage Guide

Creating a Key

Start with the free trial on the Plans page. Use the Create Account section to generate your API Key. Store your Master Password and Secret Recovery Phrase securely — we cannot recover them if lost.

Encrypting and Decrypting Passwords

Use the Store Password section to save credentials. A unique Password ID is returned upon success. Retrieve and decrypt it later in the Retrieve Password section using your Master Password.

Sharing a Password

In the Share with Team section, provide the Password ID and comma-separated API Keys of recipients. Share tokens are generated for secure, auditable access without exposing plaintext.

Creating a Share Group

Create a group in the Create Share Group section. Add or remove members using Group ID and their API Keys. Groups simplify secure sharing across teams.

Sharing Guide

QuantumSure enables secure password and token sharing without ever transmitting plaintext. Ideal for sharing access to Google Workspace, AWS, or other services.

  1. Generate and store the token/password in QuantumSure.
  2. Create a Share Token or share directly to a Group.
  3. Recipients use their own Master Password to access the shared item.

Frontend teams can integrate retrieval and decryption functions without ever knowing the actual secret.

Best Security Practices

  • Never share your Master Password or Secret Recovery Phrase.
  • Store your API Key and recovery phrase offline (preferably physically).
  • Use strong, unique Master Passwords (minimum 16 characters).
  • Enable group revocation immediately when team members leave.
  • Export credentials regularly and store them securely.

QuantumSure Encryption at a Glance

QuantumSure combines multiple layers of protection:

  • Kyber-1024 — NIST-selected post-quantum KEM based on Module-LWE (security ~ AES-256 level)
  • Fernet-like symmetric encryption — Authenticated encryption inspired by Fernet, implemented with ChaCha20 + Poly1305
  • Decoy-based obfuscation — Proprietary in-house technique that injects useless keys to mislead attackers

All encryption occurs client-side. We never see plaintext or your Master Password.
